Japanese Film as a Critique of Western Realist Cinema

An argument in 3 units.

J.A. Murphy, University of Florida

Purpose

This presentation is designed to introduce the reader to Noel Burch's To the Distant Observer to provide a starting point in understanding Western critical discussion of Japanese cinema.

Assumptions

We assume that Burch's 1979 book is a seminal work, around which the debate on Japanese film is still structured. Burch argues that a critique of Hollywood realist cinema is inscribed in Japanese film practice of the 1930's and 40's, for the Western critic. Anderson and Richie call To the Distant Observer "the most insightful account of Japanese cinema ever written" (The Japanese Film, they're not necessarily happy with his politics, though). Cited frequently through the 90's in studies of both Japanese literature and film, Burch's work still stands as "the most provocative study of the Japanese cinema in any language," (Mitsuhiro Yoshimoto, "The Difficulty of Being Radical" Boundary 2 (Fall 91)). As a point of departure for subsequent literary and film criticism, Burch's argument cannot be avoided by any serious student of Japanese culture.

Overview

Each unit follows Burch in the construction of its object, though this is not a reproduction of To the Distant Observer. The material for the images has been culled from a variety of standard sources on prewar Japanese and Hollywood film, and a number of new illustrations, techniques and arguments have been introduced. What I have tried to retain, though, in all cases, is the starkness and force of Burch's original polemic, in which an unproblematic "Japanese tradition" is mobilized to strike at what he calls "bourgeois, Western cinema." Ozu, in particular, appears in Burch's argument as an almost photographic negative of the Hollywood realist style. Though Bordwell, Desser, Lehman, and others have taken to task these and other aspects of To the Distant Observer, it is felt that the boldness of Burch's original conception is the best base from which to enter the critical debate which follows.

Unit 1.

Designed to give the student a concrete appreciation for the normative cinematographic, editing, and mise-en-scene practices characteristic of what Burch calls "Western cinema", which we call both Hollywood realist cinema and mainstream realist cinema.
[Continue to Unit 1.]

Unit 2.

Takes up the work of Ozu Yasujiro as representing the most rigorous and fully-developed example of the critique of the Hollywood style, a critique recognizable, though, in all Japanese directors of this period.
[Continue to Unit 2.]

Unit 3.

Examines aspects of Mizoguchi Kenji's works, which develop a similarly powerful critique along an altogether different stylistic path. Together, the two masters hint at the rich possibilities in telling a story with film, possibilities largely foreclosed where the norms of Hollywood realist cinema are taken as "natural."
[Continue to Unit 3.]

Concepts & Still Pictures in Multimedia: Why?

Well, one, the book is hard to follow. So it's really important to get a few key concepts and terms down. And anyone involved in teaching Japanese cinema has probably tried to illustrate these points using institutional video equipment. These experiences, involving spans of dead class time while forwarding and rewinding, remotes with a mind of their own, and poor picture quality in the "pause" mode can be frustrating to teacher and student alike.

You can conceive of this format as a series of "pause" frames organized for your convenience. Although there are disadvantages to still images, particularly where camera movement and shot pacing are concerned, they have a kind of digital precision when illustrating the kind of abstract notions, like the 180 degree line, and the eyeline match that are crucial to Burch. A slide show also has advantages over book illustrations for concepts like the graphic match. Whereas sequences of stills in a book are side by side, images in a slide show are projected sequentially in the same place, just like a movie. But I guess we lose that on the Web until I have time to figure out how to make the images appear in succession.

Finally

This presentation is no more than a highly schematic introduction. Clearly, to understand Burch's argument in all its complexity, there is no substitute for reading the book, and seeing the movies. What can be provided here, though, is a concrete and dynamic illustration of an argument which can seem daunting to beginning students. Once a firm understanding of a few basic propositions has been gained, the slides can just as easily be used to initiate discussion of the many critiques of Burch's approach, such as those by Bordwell, Desser and Lehman.

I would like to acknowledge Bordwell, Staiger and Thompson's 1985 work The Classical Hollywood Cinema, unmatched in the clarity of its exposition of CHC, which has been invaluable to me in understanding Burch's point of departure.
